s.gd: Tha fichead bliadhna o phòs Murchadh is Màiri.
s.en: It is twenty years since Murdo and Mary married.

s.gd: Tha deagh chuimhne agam air là na bàinnse.
s.en: I have a good memory of the wedding day.

s.gd: Feumaidh mi aideachadh gu robh mi duilich air an son.
s.en: I have to admit that I was sorry for them.

s.gd: Cha robh aig Murchadh a chuireadh e air ach a sheann deise ghlas, is deàrrsadh aisde leis an aois.
s.en: Murdo had nothing to wear but his old grey suit, shiny with age.

s.gd: Chunnaic gùn Màiri là na b’fheàrr, ach, le a h-ad ùir, bha i bòidheach.
s.en: Mary’s gown had seen better days, but, with her new hat, she was beautiful.

s.gd: Phòs am ministear iad anns an eaglais bhig aig ceann shuas a’ bhaile.
s.en: The minister married them in the little church at the upper end of the town.

s.gd: Dh’òl sinn an slàinte an taigh a mhàthar-san, agus thug an dotair iad na charbad gu taigh beag croiteir air taobh na beinne.
s.en: We drank their health in his mother’s house, and the doctor brought them in his car to a small crofter’s house on the side of the hill.

s.gd: Cha robh mòran fearainn aig Murchadh, ach bha dà mhart aige agus beagan chaorach.
s.en: Murdo did not have a lot of land, but he had two cows and a small number of sheep.

s.gd: Reic e bainne agus clòimh, agus, mar chaidh na bliadhnachan seachad, chuir e beagan mu seach.
s.en: He sold milk and wool, and, as the years went past, he put a little [money] aside.

s.gd: Thàinig an cogadh agus bha feum air Murchadh air an fhearann.
s.en: The war came and Murdo was needed on the land.

s.gd: Dh’oibrich e-fhèin is Màiri a là is a dh’oidhche, agus thàinig là, nuair bha an cogadh seachad, a cheannaich Murchadh tuathanachas air an robh taigh mòr geal.
s.en: He himself and Mary worked day and night, and a day came, when the war was over, that Murdo bought a farm on which there was a big white house.

s.gd: Bha iad math dheth a-nis.
s.en: They were well off now.

s.gd: Cha robh duine cloinne aca, ach bha iad sona le chèile.
s.en: They dd not have a child, but they were happy with each other.

s.gd: Ach cha d’innis mi dhuibh mun bhocsa dhubh!
s.en: But I have not told you about the black box!

s.gd: Air là àraidh, fichead bliadhna bhon là a phòs iad, bha Murchadh a’ dol gu fèill anns an ath bhaile.
s.en: On one particular day, twenty years from the day they married, Murdo was going to market in the next town.

s.gd: Dh’fheumadh e na brògan ìosal spaideil a chur air.
s.en: He had to put on the smart low shoes.

s.gd: Fhuair e aon bhròg ìosal, ach càit an robh an t’èile?
s.en: He found one low shoe, but where was the other?

s.gd: Sìos air a ghlùinean chaidh Murchadh feuch an robh i fon leabaidh.
s.en: Down on his knees, Murdo went to see if it was under the bed.

s.gd: Cha d’fhuair e a’ bhròg, ach fhuair e bocsa — bocsa dubh nach fhaca a shùilean riamh.
s.en: He did not find the show, but he found a box – a black box that his eyes had never seen.

s.gd: Tharraing e a-mach e, ach bha e glaiste.
s.en: He pulled it out, but it was locked.

s.gd: “A Mhàiri,” dh’èigh e, “gu dè a th’agad sa’ bhocsa dhubh?”
s.en: “Mary,” he called, “what do you have in the black box?”

s.gd: Thàinig Màiri is greann oirre.
s.en: Mary came wearing a frown.

s.gd: “A Mhurchaidh,” arsa ise, “ma chuireas tu corrag air a’ bhocsa dhubh, cha bhruidhinn mi riut gu sìorraidh tuilleadh.”
s.en: “Murdo,” sahe said, “if you put a finger on th black box, I will never speak to you ever again.”

s.gd: “Agus,” fhreagair Murchadh, “mur innis thu dhòmhsa gu dè a tha thu a’ cleith, cha bhruidhinn mise riutsa.”
s.en: “And,” replied Murdo, “if you don’t tell me what you are hiding, I won’t speak to you.”

s.gd: Fhuair Màiri a’ bhròg eile, agus thilg i air Murchadh i.
s.en: Mary found the other shoe, and she threw it at Murdo.

s.gd: Gun ghuth gun ghabadh chuir e uime a chuid aodaich agus dh’fhàg e Màiri leatha fhèin.
s.en: Without a word, he put on his clothes and he left Mary on her own.

s.gd: Shuidh Màiri air cathair, is na deòir a’ ruith o a sùilean.
s.en: Mary sat down on a chair, the tears running from her eyes.

s.gd: “A Mhurchaidh, a Mhurchaidh,” ghlaodh i, “nach robh de mhisneachd agamsa na dh’innseadh dhutsa an nì a tha mi a’ falach ort!”
s.en: “Murdo, Murdo,” she sobbed, “that I didn’t have confidence to tell you the thing that I am hiding from you!”

s.gd: Chaidh an là seachad agus thàinig ciaradh an fheasgair.
s.en: The day went by and dusk came.

s.gd: Cha robh sgial air Murchadh.
s.en: There was no trace of Murdo.

s.gd: Bha cridhe Màiri bhochd briste.
s.en: Poor Mary’s heart was broken.

s.gd: Is dòcha gu robh e air a bhàthadh anns an Abhainn Mhòir!
s.en: Perhaps he had drowned in the Big River!

s.gd: Is dòcha gun mharbh carbad e air an rathad air ais.
s.en: Perhaps a car had killed him on the road back.

s.gd: “Till, a Mhurchaidh, is innsidh mi dhut gu dè a tha anns a’ bhocsa!
s.en: “Come back, Murdo, and I will tell you what is in the box!

s.gd: Carson nach do loisg mi am bocsa is na tha ann o chionn fhada?”
s.en: Why did I not burn the box and what is inside long ago?”

s.gd: Bha Murchadh air an rathad dhachaigh, ceum san uair aige agus coltas glè mhì-thoilichte.
s.en: Murdo was on the road home, a step in his time and looking very unhappy.

s.gd: Cha b’fhiach prìsean; chan fhaca e mòran eòlaich; b’fheàrr leis nach d’fhalbh e riamh.
s.en: The prices had not been worth it; he had not seen many acquaintances; he shouldn’t have left at all.

s.gd: Ach cha robh cabhag dhachaigh air gu Màiri is a bocsa dubh!
s.en: But he was in no hurry home to Mary and her black box!

s.gd: Dè an sonas a bhiodh aige mur cluinneadh e guth Màiri tuilleadh?
s.en: What happiness he would have before he would hear Mary’s voice again?

s.gd: Shuidh e air cloich ri taobh an rathaid, agus le a cheann na dhà làimh rinn e suas inntinn gum b’fheàrr leis Màiri le a bocsa na bhith às a h-eugmhais buileach.
s.en: He sat down on a stome by the side of the road, and with his head in his two hands he made up his mind that he would prefer Mary with her box rather than being withour her completely.

s.gd: Dhìrich e e-fhèin agus le ceuman fada rinn e air a dhachaigh.
s.en: He straightened himself up and with long steps he made his way home.

s.gd: Chunnaic Màiri e a’ tighinn agus ruith i ga ionnsaigh.
s.en: Mary saw him coming and she ran towards him.

s.gd: “A Mhurchaidh,” ars ise, “thig còmhla riumsa is chì thusa dè a tha anns a’ bhocsa dhubh.”
s.en: “Murdo,” she said, “come along with me and you will see what is in the black box.”

s.gd: “A Mhàiri,” fhreagair Murchadh, “tha mi coma ged a bhiodh tu a’ gleidheadh cuirp ann!”
s.en: “Mary,” replied Murdo, “I am indifferent even if you would be keeping a body in it!”

s.gd: Le chèile chaidh iad a-steach, agus le a h-iuchair dh’fhosgail Màiri am bocsa.
s.en: Together they went inside, and with her key Mary opened the box.

s.gd: A measg phàipearan thug i gùn brèagha geal!
s.en: Among papers she took a beautiful white gown!

s.gd: “Gu dè a tha thu a’ dol a dhèanamh le sin?” arsa Murchadh.
s.en: “What are you going to do with that?” said Murdo.

s.gd: “Bheil cuimhne agad air là na bainnse?” arsa Màiri.
s.en: “Do you remember the wedding day?” said Mary.

s.gd: “Rinn mi an gùn seo le mo dhà làimh fhèin, ach bha fhios agam nach robh agadsa ach do sheann deise ghlas, is cha b’urrainn mi do nàrachadh.
s.en: “I made this gown with my own two hands, but I knew that you only had your old grey suit, and I couldn’t embarrass you.

s.gd: Ghlèidh mi riamh e, agus is iomadh uair a sheall mi air nuair bha mi leam fhèin.”
s.en: I kept it for ever, and many a time I looked at it when I was alone.

s.gd: “Lean mise, a Mhàiri,” arsa Murchadh, agus thug e i gu ceann shuas an t-sabhail.
s.en: “Follow me, Mary,” said Murdo, and he took her to the top end of the barn.

s.gd: A-mach às an fhodar, thug e bocsa — bocsa dubh glè choltach ri bocsa Màiri.
s.en: Out of the straw, he took a box – a black box very similar to Mary’s box.

s.gd: Dh’fhosgail e e, agus a measg phàipearan thug e deise bhriagha ghorm!
s.en: He opened it, and among papers he took a beautiful blue suit!

s.gd: “Thachair dhòmhsa mar thachair dhutsa. a Mhàiri,” ars esan.
s.en: “It happened to me as it happened to you, Mary,” he said.

s.gd: “Rinn an tàillear an deise dhomh, ach bha sinn bochd le chèile, agus cha d’innis thu dhomh gu robh gùn agad.
s.en: “The tailor made the suit for me, but we were both poor, and you didn’t tell me that you had a gown.

s.gd: Ach èisd rium a-nis, a Mhairi!
s.en: But listen to me now, Mary!

s.gd: Chì mis am ministear.
s.en: I will see the minister.

s.gd: Iarraidh mi air tighinn oidhche na Sàbaid.
s.en: I will ask him to come on Sunday night.

s.gd: Cuiridh tusa ort do ghùn, agus mise mo dheise ghorm, agus pòsaidh e sinn uair eile.”
s.en: You will put on your gown, and me my blue suit, and he will marry us one more time.”

s.gd: Mar a thubhairt, b’fhìor.
s.en: As it was said, it was true.

s.gd: Chunnaic Murchadh am ministear, agus bha am ministear deònach.
s.en: Murdo saw the minister, and the minister was willing.

s.gd: Air oidhche Sàbaid cheangail e a-rithist am paidhir a bha ceangailte fichead bliadhna — Màiri na gùn briagha geal, agus Murchadh na dheise bhriagha ghorm.
s.en: On Sunday night, he joined again the pair who had been joined for twenty years – Mary in her beautiful white gown, and Murdo in his beautiful blue suit.

s.gd: Cha dùnadh an gùn air Màiri, agus bha putan an siud is an seo fosgailte air deise Mhurchaidh, ach cha robh fiamh a’ ghàire air aodann a’ mhinisteir.
s.en: The gown did not close on Mary, and a button here and there was open on Murdo’s suit, but there was not the hint of a smile on the minister’s face.
